Working through Capture The Ether warmup challenges using Hardhat
setting up a Solidity Smart Contract development environment
, let's get started learning both how to use Hardhat, and Smart Contract security at the same time, by completing some of the challenges on
Let's start from the place we left off last time, and check out

. Rather than go through the relatively arduous process of getting some Ropsten testnet Ethereum, what we'll do is use Hardhat to simulate the entire thing (albeit without the Metamask integration - we're focusing on practicing building unit tests here).
Our challenge is simple - deploy a Smart Contract, and then verify it's deployed by interacting with it. The challenge's code is as follows:
// This tells the CaptureTheFlag contract that the challenge is complete.

, and pasting in the above Solidity code. First, note the
line at the top. This defines the spec for the version of
that will be used to compile this version. In order to compile this particular contract, we will need to tell Hardhat which versions of the Solidity compiler to download. To do this, edit your
member. It should start out containing a simple string; something like
. We want to be able to support multiple versions, so let's change this to the following, to keep support for 0.8.4, and also add support for ^0.4.21:

0.4.25 is the latest version in the 0.4 series, so we'll use that. It is possible to upgrade most of these to use the latest version of Solidity, but some of them rely on old compiler bugs, and there's not a huge amount of point in doing so this early in our learning journey. Now, let's create our unit test.
Create a new folder in the
, and then create a file in there called
. Paste the following code in there:

test group called "DeployChallenge", and a single test case within it called "should return true when deployed". Test cases should almost always be named in terms of the specific result that should occur when a given event is encountered. This makes it clear to others exactly what is being tested for.
We only have one thing that we need to check for the unit tests we'll build to solve these challenges, which is that we can cause the challenge's
. In this case, all we have to do is deploy the challenge in order to pass the test.
Running through the test line by line, we have a number of things happening. The first line retrieves an instance of a
. We pass it the Contract's name, and it will return us something that we can deploy. For simplicity, we will usually be deploying to the
in our tests. This is a slightly contrived environment, but it allows us a lot of control over what happens, allowing us to perform tests that otherwise might take hours, in a matter of seconds.

The second line asynchronously deploys the contract, returning an instance we can interact with. In order to interact with the contract, we need to then wait for the transaction to be mined by awaiting the async
method. Fortunately the Hardhat Network automatically mines transactions in the order they are received, so this call is almost instant.
Finally, the test makes sure that we've successfully deployed the contract by calling the
assertion library to confirm that it returns
. We will use this pattern at, or near the end of each test, to prove that we have solved the task.
. This should produce a successful test run as so:

Success! We've completed the task without going and searching for Ropsten testnet Ethereum! Now, let's try the next warmup -
. This challenge tests that we're able to interact with a Smart Contract. This challenge is simpler to complete inside a Hardhat development environment than it is to do via a wallet like
. In fact, our test to complete this challenge will look almost identical to the last one.

You can see here that this is exactly the same code as the previous challenge, but our test has been renamed, and we're looking up the right challenge. If we run this now, the test will fail, because we are not calling the
To make this test pass, we need to add a new line to our test:
// When we call this method, the challenge will be marked as complete

Let's run through the final warmup challenge before we sign off for today. This one's a bit more interesting than the last couple, as not only does it show how 2 smart contracts can interact with each other, but we also need to make a small modification to it in order to make it work in Hardhat. The reason we have to do this is that the code shown on the challenge's page is not exactly the same code that is running on at the contract's actual address. It is basically just enough information to pass the challenge using traditional tools like Metamask and MyEtherWallet.
To start off this challenge, create a contract with the following code:
// Relevant part of the CaptureTheEther contract.
// Challenge contract. You don't need to do anything with this; it just verifies
// that you set a nickname for yourself.
// Your address gets passed in as a constructor parameter.
// Check that the first character is not null.
You can see here that we've moved the lookup of the referred Smart Contract inside the
address parameter. This lets us tell our NicknameChallenge contract where to find the instance of the CaptureTheEther contract on which to check that your nickname has been set.

Now, let's set up our unit test. This one's going to be a little more advanced than the tests we've done so far, too - so that we can more closely mimic how we'd solve this challenge using a Hardhat script, and also explore the mocha testing environment in a little more detail, too. Create your test file as follows:
"should return true after we set our nickname"

contract. We also assign the variable

The meat of this test is where we
method and wait for the transaction to be mined. We then call our modified
method, passing in the address at which the backend is deployed. If all has gone well, we've got a third and final successful call on the Capture The Ether warmup section. As before, run
to see that the test passes successfully.
